columns.text: In this exercise, we will calculate the APR of each point from the EAR and the number of times compounded.

First, let's discuss what APR and EAR are.

- APR, the *Annual Percentage Rate* also referred to as the stated rate, is the rate calculated by multiplying the nominal rate by the number of periods in a year, representing the annual rate a lender can quote its customer as prescribed by laws. 

- EAR, otherwise known as Effective Annual Rate, refers to a loan's annual interest rate after considering the nominal interest and the compounding period.

The annual percentage rate or APR from the effective annual rate can be computed using the following equation:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{APR} &=m\left(1+EAR\right)^{\dfrac{1}{m}}-1
\end{aligned}$$

Where:

$m$, which refers to the compounding periods\
$EAR$, which refers to the effective annual rate

Let's now compute the annual percentage rate of 9% EAR compounded semi-annually.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{APR} &=2\left(1+0.111\right)^{\dfrac{1}{2}}-1
\\[10pt]
&=2\times0.054039847
\\[5pt]
&= \boxed{\bf10.8\%}
\end{aligned}$$

**Based on our calculation, the annual percentage rate or stated rate of an EAR of 9% compounded semi-annually is 10.8%.**

Now, let's calculate the annual percentage rate if the EAR is 19.6% and compounded monthly.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{APR} &=12\left(1+0.196\right)^{\dfrac{1}{12}}-1
\\[10pt]
&=12\times0.015027008
\\[5pt]
&= \boxed{\bf18.\%}
\end{aligned}$$

**As can be seen in our calculation, the stated rate, if EAR is 19.6% compounded monthly, is 18.%**

Next, solve the APR when the EAR is 10.5% and compounded weekly.

The compounding period in this calculation is the approximate number of weeks within a year. Hence in calculating the annual percentage rate, we will use a compounding factor of 52.

If the EAR is 10.5% and compounded weekly, let's determine the annual percentage rate.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{APR} &=52\left(1+0.196\right)^{\dfrac{1}{52}}-1
\\[10pt]
&=52\times0.001921947
\\[5pt]
&= \boxed{\bf10\%}
\end{aligned}$$

**Therefore, the annual percentage rate of an EAR of 10.5% compounded weekly is 10%.**

Last, calculate the APR if the EAR is 8.4% and compounded infinitely.

An annual percentage rate calculation wherein the compounding period has no end will solely consider the effective annual rate. Hence, we will use an antilog to determine the APR, input the following equation on a natural logarithm calculator:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{APR} &=Inf\left(1+EAR\right)
\end{aligned}$$

Where:

$EAR$, which refers to the effective annual rate

We'll calculate the annual percentage rate of 8.4% EAR with an infinite period using an antilog.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{APR} &=Inf\left(1+0.084\right)
\\[5pt]
&= \boxed{\bf8.1\%}
\end{aligned}$$

**Therefore, the annual percentage of the EAR is 8.4 and has an infinite compounding period is 8.1%**

To deduce, by considering the EAR and the compounding period of each case, the result of our calculations shows the following APR:

| EAR   | Compounded period | APR   |
|-------|-------------------|-------|
| 11.1% | Semi- annual      | 10.8% |
| 19.6% | Monthly           | 18.0% |
| 10.5% | Weekly            | 10.0% |
| 8.4%  | Infinite          | 8.1%  |
